message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s age and lack of other symptoms make Lyme disease and malignancy less likely. The absence of neurologic findings on exam and normal CT scan make cerebrovascular accident less likely. This leaves idiopathic (also known as Bell’s palsy) as the most likely cause, which is a commonly diagnosed condition that affects the facial nerve causing sudden weakness or paralysis on one side of the face.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of symptoms without a history of trauma or recent travel suggests an idiopathic cause of facial asymmetry, also known as Bell's palsy. Lyme disease can also cause facial paralysis but usually has a history of tick exposure or a bull's eye rash. A cerebrovascular accident or stroke would have other neurological symptoms, and malignancy is not a common cause of sudden onset facial asymmetry.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests Bell’s palsy, which is an idiopathic facial nerve palsy. Lyme disease can also cause facial nerve palsy, but the patient denies recent travel or exposure to ticks. A cerebrovascular accident or malignancy would be unlikely as the rest of the neurological exam is normal and the CT scan is unremarkable.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of symptoms and absence of any other abnormalities on physical exam or CT scan suggest idiopathic facial nerve palsy or Bell's palsy as the most likely cause. Lyme disease and cerebrovascular accident can also cause facial nerve palsy, but would be less likely in the absence of other symptoms or risk factors. Malignancy is unlikely, as there are no other findings to support this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with facial nerve palsy, which is commonly caused by idiopathic Bell’s palsy. Lyme disease can also cause facial nerve palsy, but other symptoms such as joint pain and fever would be present. A cerebrovascular accident or malignancy would be unlikely given the unremarkable CT scan of the head.

A cerebrovascular accident or malignancy is less likely given the absence of other neurological symptoms and a normal CT scan.

Lyme disease can also cause facial palsy, but there is no history of recent travel or tick exposure. A cerebrovascular accident or malignancy would likely show abnormalities on the CT scan.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests a diagnosis of idiopathic facial nerve palsy, also known as Bell’s palsy. Lyme disease and malignancy can also cause similar symptoms, but given the absence of a recent travel history or other factors that would increase the likelihood of these conditions, idiopathic is the most likely cause. A cerebrovascular accident would present with more widespread neurological deficits and a head CT scan would likely show abnormalities.

Lyme disease can cause facial nerve palsy, but the lack of travel history makes it less likely. A cerebrovascular accident or malignancy are less likely to cause facial nerve palsy without other neurological symptoms or findings on imaging.

Lyme disease may cause facial nerve palsy but typically presents with other symptoms like fever, headache, and rash. Cerebrovascular accident and malignancy would show abnormalities on the CT scan.
